posts.name: Boyu

posts.cooked:
Are you using the encoder as a relative encoder? Because if you are using it as an absolute encoder you need to use the DutyCycleEncoder class.

Also make sure you are connecting the right wires for how you want to use it. The docs for that can be found here https://docs.revrobotics.com/rev-crossover-products/sensors/tbe/application-examples

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: I used the Quadrature Encoder (Relative) described in the documentation and also switched the encoder to mode a.
Ok, where in your robot.java file are you calling resetEncoder then?
You put a int in the ela topic when you reset the encoder so it‚Äôs probably truncating the double value. See if changing it to 0.0 fixes anything

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: i change SmartDashboard.putNumber("Ela", 0); to SmartDashboard.putNumber("Ela", 0.0); but still zero

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: Also I tried unplugging and replugging the encoder during runtime, and caused a slight change in the ela value.
Could you post a link to your GitHub so I can have more context.

I don‚Äôt see anything that would be causing this. I guess you could try printing out the raw count of the encoder to see if you‚Äôre receiving data in the first place and to make sure it isn‚Äôt a smart dashboard issue (which I doubt). But if that doesn‚Äôt work, then it probably is something to do with electrical.

posts.name: Emil
posts.cooked: Whenever I get this issue it was that the sensor wires that connect into the rev throughbore encoder were not in enough. Doubt that will work in your case since ur saying you double checked the wiring, but its worth a shot.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: You could wire the index pulse to a Digital Input. It‚Äôs easy to see that pulse of 90 degrees and could indicate if the encoder has power and is doing something useful.

posts.name: Boyu
posts.cooked: Okay, I think I‚Äôve found the problem. I mistook the ‚Äús‚Äù on the robotrio for a negative pole‚Ä¶ Although, thx
